title: How to Insert a Text Box in Google Docs

steps.title: Open a Google Doc.
steps.content: Open a Google Doc. You can create or open a Google Doc through Google Drive by signing into your Google account .

steps.title: Click Insert.
steps.content: Click Insert . This tab is located at the top left of your screen under the title of your Google Doc.

steps.title: Hover over Table and click the square in the top left.
steps.content: Hover over Table and click the square in the top left. This will create a table with a single cell that will act as a border for your text. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Type or paste text into the table.
steps.content: Type or paste text into the table. Inserting the text into the table will give you a better idea of how big you want your border to be.

steps.title: Resize the table.
steps.content: Resize the table. You can adjust the size of the table by holding down on one side of the border, then dragging it and releasing at the desired size. This method can also be used to create a page border by resizing the table so it covers the entire page.

steps.title: Adjust the style of the table and border (optional).
steps.content: Adjust the style of the table and border (optional). Change the background color of the table and the border color, width, and style using the four buttons at the far right of the menu. If you do not see these buttons, click the button at the far right of the menu with three dots as its icon. You should now see these options at the right of the sub-menu that appears.

steps.title: Open a Google Doc.
steps.content: Open a Google Doc. You can create or open a Google Doc through Google Drive by signing into your Google account .

steps.title: Click in front of the piece of text you would like to put a box around.
steps.content: Click in front of the piece of text you would like to put a box around. If you have multiple pieces of text in a document and only want a border around certain text, be sure you start each paragraph on a new line.

steps.title: Click Format.
steps.content: Click Format . This menu shows you a variety of adjustments you can make to the formatting of your page and content.

steps.title: Hover over Paragraph styles and select Borders and shading.
steps.content: Hover over Paragraph styles and select Borders and shading . You should now see a pop-up window titled “Borders and shading” with a variety of border customization options. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Click the first four boxes next to “Position”.
steps.content: Click the first four boxes next to “Position”. Each of these boxes corresponds to a different line in your border, so enabling all of them will fully construct your text box.

steps.title: Customize your border (optional).
steps.content: Customize your border (optional). Adjust your border width, style, color, background color, and space between your border and your text using the dropdown menus to the right of each heading.

steps.title: Click Apply.
steps.content: Click Apply . You should now see a box around your text!

steps.title: Resize your text box (optional).
steps.content: Resize your text box (optional). This method will create a box around your text that spans the entire width of the page. If you would like to shrink the box, click next to your text, then adjust the margins of that paragraph by dragging the blue arrows at the top of your page to the desired spots.

steps.title: Open a Google Doc.
steps.content: Open a Google Doc. You can create or open a Google Doc through Google Drive by signing into your Google account .

steps.title: Click Insert.
steps.content: Click Insert . This tab is located at the top left of your screen under the title of your Google Doc.

steps.title: Hover over Drawing and select New.
steps.content: Hover over Drawing and select New . You should now see a pop-up window titled “Drawing”. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Click the Text box icon.
steps.content: Click the Text box icon. This icon looks like a “T” in a box.

steps.title: Draw your text box.
steps.content: Draw your text box. Click and drag to create a text box of the size you choose.

steps.title: Type your desired text.
steps.content: Type your desired text. You can adjust the font, font size, color, and more using the menu at the top of the Drawing window. Once you have typed your text, consider resizing the text box once more to accommodate the size of its content.

steps.title: Click the Border weight icon and select a weight.
steps.content: Click the Border weight icon and select a weight. This button is represented by three lines stacked on top of each other with the thickest line at the top. Weight translates to border thickness, so the higher the weight you select, the thicker your border.

steps.title: Customize other border settings (optional).
steps.content: Customize other border settings (optional). Use the buttons immediately to the left and right of the Border weight button to change the fill color of your text box, the border color, and the border line style.

steps.title: Click Save and Close.
steps.content: Click Save and Close . You have now created a box around text in Google Docs! Be aware that resizing Drawings in a Google Doc can sometimes pixelate the text they contain, especially if you are shrinking them, so consider adjusting the size by clicking the Drawing, then clicking Edit instead.

steps.title: Open a Google Doc.
steps.content: Open a Google Doc. You can create or open a Google Doc through Google Drive by signing into your Google account .

steps.title: Click Insert.
steps.content: Click Insert . This tab is located at the top left of your screen under the title of your Google Doc.

steps.title: Hover over Drawing and select New.
steps.content: Hover over Drawing and select New . You should now see a pop-up window titled “Drawing”.

steps.title: Click the Shapes button.
steps.content: Click the Shapes button. This button is represented by a circle overlapping a square.

steps.title: Hover over Shapes and select the rectangle.
steps.content: Hover over Shapes and select the rectangle. The rectangle is the first option in the first category of shapes.

steps.title: Draw your rectangle.
steps.content: Draw your rectangle. Click and drag in the Drawing window to create a rectangle of the desired size.

steps.title: Double-click the rectangle and add your text.
steps.content: Double-click the rectangle and add your text. You can adjust the font, font size, color, and more using the menu at the top of the Drawing window.

steps.title: Resize the rectangle to fit your text.
steps.content: Resize the rectangle to fit your text. Adjusting the size of the rectangle in the Drawing rather than the Google Doc itself will help prevent the pixelation of your text.

steps.title: Adjust the style of the rectangle as desired (optional).
steps.content: Adjust the style of the rectangle as desired (optional). Use the four buttons in the middle of the Drawing window menu to adjust the fill color and border weight, color, and style of your rectangle.

steps.title: Click Save and Close.
steps.content: Click Save and Close . You now have text in a box in a Google Doc! If you plan on resizing your Drawing, consider doing so by clicking it, then clicking the Edit button that appears. Adjusting a Drawing’s size in a Google Doc can pixelate the text it contains.

steps.title: Open a Google Doc.
steps.content: Open a Google Doc. You can create or open a Google Doc through Google Drive by signing into your Google account .

steps.title: Click Insert.
steps.content: Click Insert . This tab is located at the top left of your screen under the title of your Google Doc.

steps.title: Hover over Drawing and select New.
steps.content: Hover over Drawing and select New . You should now see a pop-up window titled “Drawing”.

steps.title: Click the Image button.
steps.content: Click the Image button. This button icon looks like two mountains or triangles in a square and is the furthest right option in the Drawing window menu.

steps.title: Choose the Search tab.
steps.content: Choose the Search tab. If you already have a border selected and saved to your computer, choose Upload instead, then drag and drop the image into the box or select it from your files. You can also skip the next step.

steps.title: Search for something like document border.
steps.content: Search for something like document border . You can use more or less specific terms depending on the type of border you are looking for. To look through the available borders, simply scroll as you normally would through the search results.

steps.title: Click the border you like, then press Select.
steps.content: Click the border you like, then press Select . An image of the border should now be in your Drawing window.

steps.title: Click the Text box icon.
steps.content: Click the Text box icon. This icon looks like a “T” in a box.

steps.title: Draw your text box inside the border.
steps.content: Draw your text box inside the border. Be sure to shape your text box to the border; otherwise, it will not display properly.

steps.title: Type your text into the textbox.
steps.content: Type your text into the textbox. If you need more room, try resizing both the border and the text box by clicking each one, then dragging the corners further out. You can adjust the font, font size, color, and more using the menu at the top of the Drawing window.

steps.title: Click Save and Close.
steps.content: Click Save and Close . Your Drawing should now be visible in your Google Doc!

steps.title: Adjust the Drawing as desired in the Google Doc (optional).
steps.content: Adjust the Drawing as desired in the Google Doc (optional). If resizing the border in the Google Doc itself pixelates the text or image, try clicking it, then clicking Edit and resizing it in the Drawing window.
